intro: Cissus wightii, commonly known as the Indian devil's backbone, is a climbing plant native to South and Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Vitaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are followed by clusters of round, fleshy fruits. Its leaves are often used in traditional medicine for their purported healing properties. Cissus wightii is also valued as a ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and ability to climb.
